record.title: Sometsuke Take Zara (dish with cobalt hand-painted bamboo)
record.source: Burke Museum of Natural History and Culture, US Air Force Collection
record.description: Mending sherds of a sara of indeterminate size. Vessel has hand-painted bamboo elements on the interior along with a central element or medallion that is too fragmentary to identify, and two blue bands on the exterior base.
record.dimensions: Footring~ 8 cm
record.man-range: Minimalistic hand-painted sometsuke may indicate Taisho-era (1912-1926) manufacture
record.publisher: University of Idaho Library Digital Initiatives

record.dimensions: Rim~ 11 cm

record.title: Suyehiro Sometsuke Doban Gohan Jawan (rice/soup bowl with cobalt transferprint fans)
record.source: Burke Museum of Natural History and Culture, US Air Force Collection
record.description: This vessel is most likely a small rice bowl or large teacup. Decoration consists of overlapping fans that contain cherry blossom, bat, and moon elements.
record.dimensions: Rim~ 11 cm, footring~ 4.5 cm
record.man-range: Most popular in the Meiji (1868-1912) and Taisho (1912-1926) eras

record.title: Doban Chawan (transferprint bowl)
record.source: Burke Museum of Natural History and Culture, US Air Force Collection
record.description: Base and footring of a rice or side bowl. Decoration is an abstract botanical design with blue trellis-like shapes, leaves, and brown flowers. The Kikusui export mark has been identified at sites throughout the West that were occupied between approximately 1900 and 1945 (Burton 2005:96; Costello et al. 2001:33-34; Costello and Maniery 1988:27,83; Ross 2012:25-26). Research by Bibb (2007:5) suggests that this mark may have been applied to Japanese ceramics as early as 1902 in accordance with British import laws, although the US customs did not require the "Japan" mark until 1921.
record.dimensions: Footring= 4.5 cm
record.marks: Transferprint mark on base: "TRADEMARK/ [Kikusui, or chrysanthemum on water ]/MADE IN/JAPAN"
record.man-range: Most popular in the Meiji (1868-1912) and Taisho (1912-1926) eras
record.publisher: University of Idaho Library Digital Initiatives
record.rights: Copyright under creative commons license. Images available for reuse in educational (non-commercial) instances; see license details at Creative Commons.
record.citation: Photo courtesy of the Burke Museum of Natural History and Culture, catalog no. 45SN398B/2007/224, US Air Force Collection, held in trust at the Burke Museum, Seattle. See citation guidelines.

record.title: Doban Ume Soba-Choko (noodle cup with transferprint plum)
record.source: Burke Museum of Natural History and Culture, US Air Force Collection
record.description: These sherds are most likely from a soba choko based on the vessel size and shape. Soba choko are intended to hold sauce that cold soba noodles are dipped into (Costello et al. 2001:36). The popularity of green transferprint peaked in the 1920s or 1930s.
record.dimensions: Base= 6.5 cm
record.man-range: The dominantly green transferprint may indicate manufacture during or shortly after the Taisho era (1912-1926)
record.publisher: University of Idaho Library Digital Initiatives
record.rights: Copyright under creative commons license. Images available for reuse in educational (non-commercial) instances; see license details at Creative Commons.
record.citation: Photo courtesy of the Burke Museum of Natural History and Culture, catalog no. 45SN398B/2007/1692, US Air Force Collection, held in trust at the Burke Museum, Seattle. See citation guidelines.

record.title: Sometsuke Fuku Chawan (bowl with cobalt hand-painted 'luck')
record.source: Burke Museum of Natural History and Culture, US Air Force Collection
record.description: Vessel body and rim fragment. The rim diameter suggests this vessel is a type of chawan. Decoration consists of a partial character, 福 (fuku or luck), in circular medallion on the vessel exterior.
record.dimensions: Rim~ 12 cm
record.ex-dec-elements: Horizontal band around footring, indeterminate, written characters
record.marks: Mark on vessel side-wall is part of the character for fuku (福), which means luck.
record.man-range: Meiji (1868-1912) through early Showa (1926-1989) eras
record.publisher: University of Idaho Library Digital Initiatives
record.rights: Copyright under creative commons license. Images available for reuse in educational (non-commercial) instances; see license details at Creative Commons.
record.citation: Photo courtesy of the Burke Museum of Natural History and Culture, catalog no. 45SN398B/2007/2059B, US Air Force Collection, held in trust at the Burke Museum, Seattle. See citation guidelines.

record.title: Sometsuke (hand-painted cobalt) Vessel [1]
record.source: Burke Museum of Natural History and Culture, US Air Force Collection
record.description: This sherd is possibly from a small bowl, teacup, or sake cup. The decoration present consists of bands around the footring and linear elements that may be matsu (pine) needles, which are a common symbol of strength, fidelity, prosperity, and, when depicted as needle pairs, of unfailing devotion. Depictions can be highly stylized (Gorham 1971:209-210; Ross 2012:20)
record.dimensions: Footring= 4 cm
record.ex-dec-elements: Horizontal band around footring, indeterminate (possible matsu [pine] needles)
record.marks: Hand-painted base mark is too stylized to read.
record.origin: Possibly the Seto or Mino region, Japan
record.man-range: Minimalistic hand-painted sometsuke may indicate Taisho-era (1912-1926) manufacture
record.publisher: University of Idaho Library Digital Initiatives
record.rights: Copyright under creative commons license. Images available for reuse in educational (non-commercial) instances; see license details at Creative Commons.
record.citation: Photo courtesy of the Burke Museum of Natural History and Culture, catalog no. 45SN398B/2007/234Q, US Air Force Collection, held in trust at the Burke Museum, Seattle. See citation guidelines.

record.title: Bottom of Sometsuke Gohan Jawan (hand-painted cobalt rice/soup bowl)
Side of Sometsuke Gohan Jawan (hand-painted cobalt rice/soup bowl)

record.source: Burke Museum of Natural History and Culture, US Air Force Collection
record.description: This vessel is a nearly complete, deep bowl with an inverted rim that is slightly larger than the average gohan chawan and may have been intended as a soup bowl.
record.dimensions: Rim~ 10.75 cm, footring= 4.8 cm, height= 7 cm
record.marks: Hand-painted, incomplete base mark reads Arashi-yama. The district of Arashiyama is located on the outskirts of western Kyoto, and shares its name with a nearby mountain. Arashiyama can also be a family name.
record.man-range: Meiji (1868-1912) through early Showa (1926-1989) eras

record.source: Burke Museum of Natural History and Culture, US Air Force Collection

record.title: Side of Sometsuke Botan Doban Mamezara (sauce dish with cobalt transferprint peony)

Bottom of Sometsuke Botan Doban Mamezara (sauce dish with cobalt transferprint peony)
Sometsuke Botan Doban Mamezara (sauce dish with cobalt transferprint peony)
record.source: Burke Museum of Natural History and Culture, US Air Force Collection
record.description: Mamezara like the one pictured above are very small dishes traditionally used for condiments or sweets (Walter 2012:128). These mending sherds have slightly everted rims and a greyish-white paste, grainy with temper, which may be hanjiki (half porcelain) (Crueger et al. 2006:284).
record.dimensions: Rim= 7.2 cm, footring= 2.6 cm, height= 2 cm
record.man-range: Most popular in the Meiji (1868-1912) and Taisho (1912-1926) eras

record.title: Side of Kyusu No Totte (teapot handle)
Bottom of Kyusu No Totte (teapot handle)
Kyusu No Totte (teapot handle)
record.source: Burke Museum of Natural History and Culture, US Air Force Collection
record.description: This small, hollow handle is most likely from a kyusu. The diameter is approximately 2 cm at the rim and narrows to approximately 1 cm at the neck; the bore diameter measures approximately 0.5 cm. Simpson et al. (2014:106) note that unless they are thrown by an experienced potter, teapot handles are often weak points in the vessel.

record.description: Mending sherds of a katagami-stenciled gohan chawan. The interior decoration consists of a pendant yoraku rim and a center medallion containing sho chiku bai (three friends) elements. The bowl exteriror also has depeictions of sho chiku bai in rounded and arched medalions and horzontal bands around the footring.

record.title: Exterior of Sansui Dobin (landscape teapot)
Interior of Sansui Dobin (landscape teapot)
Sansui Dobin (landscape teapot) Compound Object
record.source: Burke Museum of Natural History and Culture, US Air Force Collection
record.description: Sansui Dobin rim sherd. The exterior is dipped in white slip (kohiki), hand-painted with splotches of copper-green glaze and an iron-brown linear landscape, then sealed under a colorless glaze; the vessel interior is left unglazed and undecorated. These teapots were widely distributed on the domestic market and became an iconic favorite of Mingei co-founder Yanagi Soetsu in the 1920s and 1930s (Brandt 1996; Cort 2000:230). Minagawa Masu (1875-1960), who worked throughout Mashiko, is known for painting the brown and green linear landscapes characteristic of this style (Crueger et al. 2006:220). Examples of her work are captured in a 1934 film by Bernard Leach and look strikingly similar to the example in this collection (Gross 1984).
record.dimensions: Rim~ 11 cm
record.origin: Likely either Koyama in the Shigaraki region or Mashiko in the northern Kanto region, Japan
record.man-range: Most popular in the Taisho (1912-1926) and early Showa (1926-1989) eras
record.publisher: University of Idaho Library Digital Initiatives
record.rights: Copyright under creative commons license. Images available for reuse in educational (non-commercial) instances; see license details at Creative Commons.
record.citation: Photo courtesy of the Burke Museum of Natural History and Culture, catalog no. 45SN398B/2007/1605, US Air Force Collection, held in trust at the Burke Museum, Seattle. See citation guidelines.

record.title: Side of Suribachi (grinding bowl) [2]
Top of Suribachi (grinding bowl) [2]
Bottom of Suribachi (grinding bowl) [2]
Suribachi (grinding bowl) [2]
record.source: Asian American Comparative Collection
record.description: Suribachi are used for grinding ingredients like sesame seeds and for mixing miso with other ingredients (Ross 2012:13-14). This bowl has an unglazed interior surface that has been combed (kushime) to create parallel incised lines that form an abrasive surface (Simpson 2014:58.89). The exterior has a brown glaze that extends over the rim.
record.dimensions: Rim= 16 cm, footring= 8 cm, height= 7 cm
record.man-range: Meiji (1868-1912) through Showa (1926-1989) eras
record.publisher: University of Idaho Library Digital Initiatives

record.ex-dec-method: Fukizumi (spatter stencil), Etsuke (hand painted), SumiHajiki (ink resist)

record.title: Side of Kuro Fukizumi Take Yunomi (teacup with black stenciled bamboo design)
record.ex-dec-method: Fukizumi (spatter stencil), Etsuke (hand painted), SumiHajiki (ink resist)

record.title: Base of Kuro Fukizumi Take Yunomi (teacup with black stenciled bamboo design)
record.ex-dec-method: Fukizumi (spatter stencil), Etsuke (hand painted), SumiHajiki (ink resist)

record.title: Kuro Fukizumi Take Yunomi (teacup with black stenciled bamboo design)
record.source: Asian American Comparative Collection
record.description: This yunomi is decorated with fukizumi- stenciled black pigment that creates a bamboo stalk and several leaves. Though other forms of stenciling declined in the Taisho period, fukizumi has remained in use (Crueger et al. 2001:51,286; Ross 2009:155). Hand painting and several ink resist lines are used to create small branches and veins in the bamboo leaves. The vessel also has a single reddish-brown band along the rim and a footring with a circular recess in the center that resembles a janome (bull's-eye or snake-eye recess) (Ross 2012:10).
record.dimensions: Rim= 8 cm, footring= 3.5 cm, height= 5 cm
record.ex-dec-method: Fukizumi (spatter stencil), Etsuke (hand painted), SumiHajiki (ink resist)
record.man-range: Likely Taisho (1912-1926) through pre-WWII Showa (1926-1942) era

record.title: Side of Sometsuke Doban Matsu Gohan Jawan (rice/soup bowl with cobalt transferprinted pine tree)
Side fo Sometsuke Doban Matsu Gohan Jawan (rice/soup bowl with cobalt transferprinted pine tree)
Bottom of Sometsuke Doban Matsu Gohan Jawan (rice/soup bowl with cobalt transferprinted pine tree)
Sometsuke Doban Matsu Gohan Jawan (rice/soup bowl with cobalt transferprinted pine tree)
record.source: Asian American Comparative Collection
record.description: This gohan chawan is decorated with a transferprint image of a pine tree and several horizontal carved bands on the exterior. Wooden knives, bamboo tools, or metal instruments are often used to carve lines such as these into ceramic forms (Gorham 1971:209-210; Simpson et al. 2014:60). The interior of the vessel is undecorated. This vessel was donated to the AACC by the Palouse Asian American Association.
record.dimensions: Rim= 12 cm, footring= 4.1 cm, height= 4.8 cm
record.man-range: Most popular in the Meiji (1868-1912) and Taisho (1912-1926) eras

record.description: This small gohan chawan is transferprinted on the exterior only. Two images of botan, or peony, decorate the outside of the vessel (Dower 1971:70). This vessel was donated to the AACC by John Eldredge.

record.title: Side of Iro Fukizumi Gohan Jawan (polychrome stenciled rice/soup bowl)
Side of Iro Fukizumi Gohan Jawan (polychrome stenciled rice/soup bowl)
Bottom of Iro Fukizumi Gohan Jawan (polychrome stenciled rice/soup bowl)
Iro Fukizumi Gohan Jawan (polychrome stenciled rice/soup bowl)
record.source: Asian American Comparative Collection, Minidoka Collection
record.description: This gohan chawan fragment features polychrome decoration that is applied both under and over the glaze. Cobalt cherry blossoms and brown geometric shapes that may represent sun rays are applied with an air-brush-like fukizumi method under the glaze (Crueger et al. 2001:51,286; Dower 1971:50-51; Ross 2009:155). An orange cherry blossom has been hand painted or possibly stamped on top of the glaze. The vessel has a reddish orange 'Made in Japan' mark on the base. This vessel was donated to the AACC by Ron James.
record.dimensions: Rim~ 12 cm, footring~ 4.2 cm, height= 6.2 cm
record.man-range: Likely Taisho (1912-1926) through pre-WWII Showa (1926-1942) era

record.title: Side of Samehada-Gusuri Dobin (shark-skin glaze teapot)
Side of Samehada-Gusuri Dobin (shark-skin glaze teapot)

Bottom of Samehada-Gusuri Dobin (shark-skin glaze teapot)
Samehada-Gusuri Dobin (shark-skin glaze teapot)
record.source: Asian American Comparative Collection
record.description: This dobin has a western-style handle and spout and is decorated with a shark-skin (samehada-gusuri) glaze that has a glossy, bumpy texture (Crueger et al. 2006:293; Ross 2012:9). Several botanical elements have been applied over this glaze in raised enamel or slip. The interior of the teapot is undecorated and unglazed.
record.dimensions: Rim= 8 cm, base= 8 cm, height= 11 cm
record.man-range: Meiji (1868-1912) through Showa (1926-1989) eras

record.title: Side of Sometsuke Doban Tsuru Komori Gohan Jawan (rice/soup bowl with cobalt transferprint bat and crane design)
Side of Sometsuke Doban Tsuru Komori Gohan Jawan (rice/soup bowl with cobalt transferprint bat and crane design)
Bottom of Sometsuke Doban Tsuru Komori Gohan Jawan (rice/soup bowl with cobalt transferprint bat and crane design)
record.marks: Four characters, 江西 謹製, and ""MADE IN JAPAN"" on base

record.title: Sometsuke Doban Tsuru Komori Gohan Jawan (rice/soup bowl with cobalt transferprint bat and crane design)
record.source: Asian American Comparative Collection
record.description: This gohan chawan features a rim design of clouds above repeating crane and bat elements with peaches (Dower 1971:70, 88, 90). Bats and peaches are commonly paired on Chinese ceramics, but this vessel presents a distinctly Japanese interpretation of the Chinese design. The base of the vessel is marked 'MADE IN JAPAN' and contains the four characters 江西 謹製 (Enishi kinsei) that roughly translate to 'humbly made by Enishi.'
record.dimensions: Rim= 11.5 cm, footring= 4.5 cm, height= 6 cm
record.marks: Four characters '江西 謹製' and 'MADE IN JAPAN' on base
record.man-range: Meiji (1868-1912) through Showa (1926-1989) eras
record.publisher: University of Idaho Library Digital Initiatives

record.title: Top of Imari Asagao Namasu-Zara (Imari pickle dish with morning glory design)
Bottom of Imari Asagao Namasu-Zara (Imari pickle dish with morning glory design)
Side of Imari Asagao Namasu-Zara (Imari pickle dish with morning glory design)
Imari Asagao Namasu-Zara (Imari pickle dish with morning glory design)
record.source: Asian American Comparative Collection
record.description: Likely a product of the late Tokugawa or early Meiji era, this Imari-style namasu-zara is decorated with a hand-painted morning glory design in what appears to be a gosu (natural cobalt) pigment (Dower 1971:64; Ross 2012:5). Like artifact AACC-2000-224, this pickle dish has a scalloped rim and a janome (bull's-eye or snake-eye recess) on the base (Ross 2012:10). This vessel was donated to the AACC by Alison Stenger.
record.dimensions: Rim= 13.3 cm, footring= 7.9 cm, height= 3.5 cm
record.man-range: Most popular during the Tokugawa (1603-1868) or early Meiji (1868-1912) eras

record.title: Side of Sometsuke Katagami Sho Chiku Bai Kobachi (small bowl with cobalt stenciled three friends design)

record.int-dec-elements: Sho Chiku Bai (three friends), Tassel Yoraku (rim design)

record.title: Bottom of Sometsuke Katagami Sho Chiku Bai Kobachi (small bowl with cobalt stenciled three friends design)
Sometsuke Katagami Sho Chiku Bai Kobachi (small bowl with cobalt stenciled three friends design)
record.source: Asian American Comparative Collection
record.description: This kobachi has katagami stenciling on the interior and exterior. The interior of the bowl has a tassel yoraku design around the rim and a central medallion with images of Sho Chiku Bai. The exterior features plum blossoms and highly stylized pine elements (Gorham 1971:210-211; Ross 2012:20). Katagami decoration was most popular in Japan before the development of transferprint technology and experienced the most use between the early and mid-Meiji era (Bibb 2001:5-6; Ross 2009:155).
record.dimensions: Rim= 10.4 cm, footring= 4.5 cm, height= 3.8 cm
record.int-dec-elements: Sho Chiku Bai (three friends), Tassel Yoraku (rim design)

Sometsuke Doban Sho Chiku Bai Tokkuri (sake decanter with cobalt transferprint three friends design)
record.source: Asian American Comparative Collection
record.description: This example of a very small tokkuri has a transferprinted exterior that features trailing karakusa above an image of pine, plum, and bamboo (Gorham 1971:201; Ross 2012:20-23). Small tokkuri like this one were sometimes given out by Japanese sake manufacturers, distributors, or stores as promotional items (Bibb 2013:[7]).

record.title: Bottom of Sometsuke Katagami Seigaiha Tsutsu Yunomi (cylindrical teacup with stenciled blue sea waves)

record.title: Sometsuke Katagami Seigaiha Tsutsu Yunomi (cylindrical teacup with stenciled blue sea waves)
record.source: Asian American Comparative Collection
record.description: This tsutsu yunomi has katagami stenciled designs on the vessel interior and exterior. A pendant-style yoraku rim design extends into the cup interior from the rim; the exterior is covered in a repeating blue sea waves diaper and several medallions that feature alternating images of botanical elements, one of which may be millet or rice grain (Dower 1971:63, 77; Ross 2012:21; Simpson et al. 2014:72, 94). Katagami decoration was most popular in Japan before transferprint technology was developed and experienced the most use between the early and mid-Meiji era (Bibb 2001:5-6; Ross 2009:155).

record.title: Side of Saka-Bin (sake bottle) [1]
Bottom of Saka-Bin (sake bottle) [1]
Saka-Bin (sake bottle) [1]
record.source: Asian American Comparative Collection
record.description: Saka-bin are Western-style ceramic bottles used to store and serve sake. Archaeological examples have been identified by Costello and Maniery (1988:82-85) and Ross (2012:12). This example, the larger of the two in the AACC collection, appears to be made of hanjiki (a type of half-porcelain) with a greyish-white exterior glaze. This vessel was donated to the AACC by Max Chan.

record.title: Top of Sometsuke Doban Hata Kozara (small dish with transferprint flags)
Bottom of Sometsuke Doban Hata Kozara (small dish with transferprint flags)
Side of Sometsuke Doban Hata Kozara (small dish with transferprint flags)
Sometsuke Doban Hata Kozara (small dish with transferprint flags)
record.source: Asian American Comparative Collection
record.description: The central image on this kozara is of a three-leaved paulownia flower flanked by two naval flags. The paulowina flower is associated with the imperial family. The two naval flags help date this plate to between 1889 and 1945. The text above the flags (帝国 萬歳) reads Teikoku Banzai, or 'Hurray for the empire!' Stylized chrysanthemums, also symbols of the Japanese imperial family, extend from the central medallion to a subtly scalloped rim (Dower 1971:52, 68, 112).
record.dimensions: Rim= 15.3 cm, footring= 6.8 cm, height= 2.1 cm
record.man-range: Mid-Meiji through early Showa eras (1889-1945)
record.publisher: University of Idaho Library Digital Initiatives
record.rights: Copyright under creative commons license. Images available for reuse in educational (non-commercial) instances; see license details at Creative Commons.

record.title: Top of Sometsuke Katagami Mitsu-Domoe Kozara (small dish with stenciled yin-yang design)
record.int-dec-elements: Karakusa (tendrils), Mitsu-Domoe (threefold swirl), Tsuru (crane), Ume (plum) blossom, Seven Jewels and Turtle Shell diaper

record.title: Bottom of Sometsuke Katagami Mitsu-Domoe Kozara (small dish with stenciled yin-yang design)
Side of Sometsuke Katagami Mitsu-Domoe Kozara (small dish with stenciled yin-yang design)
Sometsuke Katagami Mitsu-Domoe Kozara (small dish with stenciled yin-yang design)
record.source: Asian American Comparative Collection
record.description: This heavily-decorated kozara features multiple elements on the interior that include a mitsu-domoe in a halo of fire, a red-headed crane surrounded by trailing karakusa, images of plum and possibly chrysanthemum flowers, and a balustrade that is reminiscent of the fencing surrounding a Shinto shrine. The exterior of the dish is undecorated. Katagami, which often covers large portions of a vessel surface with small, repeating geometric patterns, was most popular as a method of decorating mass-produced porcelains in the early to mid-Meiji era (Bibb 2001:5-6). This vessel was donated by the Palouse Asian American Association.
record.dimensions: Rim= 12.5 cm, footring= 7.5 cm, height= 1.9 cm
record.int-dec-elements: Karakusa (tendrils), Mitsu-Domoe (threefold swirl), Tsuru (crane), Ume (plum) blossom, Seven Jewels and Turtle Shell diaper

record.title: Side of Sometsuke Botan Dobin (teapot with hand-painted peonies in cobalt)
Side of Sometsuke Botan Dobin (teapot with hand-painted peonies in cobalt)
Top of Sometsuke Botan Dobin (teapot with hand-painted peonies in cobalt)
Bottom of Sometsuke Botan Dobin (teapot with hand-painted peonies in cobalt)
Sometsuke Botan Dobin (teapot with hand-painted peonies in cobalt)
record.source: Asian American Comparative Collection
record.description: This dobin-style teapot features a somewhat abstracted hand-painted peony design on the exterior and a single tassel yoraku (rim design) on the spout (Dower 1971:70;Ross 2012:21). Two small lugs indicate that it would likely have had a bamboo handle. A very similar teapot was recovered archaeologically from the Riverside, California, Chinatown, dated to 1871 through 1939 (Great Basin Foundation 1987:293, Figure 18). This vessel was donated to the AACC by Ilene Buys.
record.dimensions: Rim= 8 cm, base= 7 cm, height= 11 cm

record.title: Bottom of Sometsuke Katagami Sakura Gohan Jawan (rice/soup bowl with cobalt stenciled cherry blossom design)
Sometsuke Katagami Sakura Gohan Jawan (rice/soup bowl with cobalt stenciled cherry blossom design)
record.source: Asian American Comparative Collection
record.description: The exterior of this katagami stenciled gohan chawan is covered in a repeating cherry blossom design separated by a dot-diaper pattern (Dower 1971:50-51). The interior of the bowl has a tassel yoraku design around the rim and a central medallion with images of sho chiku bai (Gorham 1971:201; Ross 2012:21). This vessel was donated to the AACC by Paula Rosa.

record.title: Top of Ho-o Zara (Phoenix Ware dish/plate)
Bottom of Ho-o Zara (Phoenix Ware dish/plate)
Side of Ho-o Zara (Phoenix Ware dish/plate)
Ho-o Zara (Phoenix Ware dish/plate)
record.source: Asian American Comparative Collection
record.description: This Western-style dish is in the form of a saucer. The interior transferprint design of Ho-o birds, karakusa tendrils, and paulownia and chrysanthemum flowers identify it as what is known in the West as Phoenix Ware (Dower 1971:52, 68-69; Ross 2012:20,23; Walter 2012:125, 129). The rim of the plate features an adaption of the Chinese cloud and mountain motif (Oats 1984:18). Commonly mis-identified as a Phoenix or a turkey in the West, the Ho-o, or houou, bird is a composite animal, adapted from Chinese mythology, that incorporates parts of several creatures such as the rooster, mandarin duck, peacock, crane, and pheasant. Both the paulownia flower and the Ho-o bird are symbols of the Empress (Walter 2012:125, 129). Ho-o designs became immensely popular exports on Western forms just prior to 1914 and remained so until the 1930s (Van Patten 1994:60).
record.dimensions: Rim= 14 cm, footring= 8 cm, height= 2 cm
record.man-range: Most popular Taisho (1912-1926) through very early Showa (1926-1989) era
record.publisher: University of Idaho Library Digital Initiatives
record.rights: Copyright under creative commons license. Images available for reuse in educational (non-commercial) instances; see license details at Creative Commons.
record.citation: Photo courtesy of the Asian American Comparative Collection, catalog no. AACC-2008-077. See citation guidelines.

record.title: Side of Doban Sen (transferprint coin) Vessel
Side of Doban Sen (transferprint coin) Vessel
Doban Sen (transferprint coin) Vessel
record.source: Burke Museum of Natural History and Culture, US Air Force Collection
record.description: This vessel base and footring fragment is decorated with a green transferprint design under a grainy glaze. The decoration features two overlapping coins. The top coin appears to be a variation of the Japanese Kan'ei Tsuhou, which was manufactured throughout the Tokugawa period (1603-1868) (Hartill 2011:38). Japanese potters did not develope green underglaze pigments for porcelain until the 1870s and 1880s; however, so that by the time this artifact was manufactured, the Kan'ei Tsuhou was no longer being produced (Ross 2009:156).
record.dimensions: Footring= 4 cm
record.man-range: Most popular in the late Taisho (1912-1926) and early Showa (1926-1989) eras
record.publisher: University of Idaho Library Digital Initiatives
record.rights: Copyright under creative commons license. Images available for reuse in educational (non-commercial) instances; see license details at Creative Commons.

record.title: Doban Yin-Yo Gohan Jawan (rice/soup bowl with transferprint yin-yang)
record.source: Burke Museum of Natural History and Culture, US Air Force Collection
record.description: The size and shape of this vessel fragment indicate that is likely from a gohan chawan. The interior is undecorated, but the exterior contains images of yin-yang elements in transferprint cobalt blue and green (Gorham 1971:220).
record.dimensions: Rim= 12 cm, height= 7 cm
record.man-range: Meiji (1868-1912) through Showa (1926-1989) eras

record.title: Sometsuke Senbori Gohan Jawan (rice/soup bowl with hand-painted cobalt and carved lines)
record.source: Asian American Comparative Collection, Minidoka Collection
record.description: Although incomplete, the size and shape of this fragment indicate that it is likely a piece of a gohan chawan. The sherd features hand-painted bamboo elements and several carved horizontal bands (Dower 1971:46; Simpson et al. 2014:60). Japanese ceramics expert Leland Bibb (2013:[11]) has suggested that this minimalistic style of hand-painting became most popular in the Taisho and early Showa eras. This vessel was donated to the AACC by Ron James.
record.dimensions: Rim~ 12 cm, footring~ 4 cm, height= 6.5 cm
record.man-range: Likely Taisho (1912-1926) through pre-WWII Showa (1926-1942) era

record.rights: Copyright under creative commons license. Images available for reuse in educational (non-commercial) instances; see license details at Creative Commons.

record.title: Sometsuke Doban Choju Yunomi (teacup with cobalt transferprint longevity design)
record.source: Asian American Comparative Collection
record.description: This yunomi is transferprinted on the interior and exterior surfaces. A tassel yoraku design encircles the interior rim; the cup's exterior contains alternating panels of pine, plum, or bamboo (known collectively as Sho Chiku Bai), and the character for longevity.

record.title: Side of Seiji Gohan Jawan (Winter Green rice bowl)

Seiji Gohan Jawan (Winter Green rice bowl)
record.source: Asian American Comparative Collection
record.description: This gohan chawan features a bright green seiji glaze on the exterior and has an undecorated interior. This vessel was donated to the AACC by Alison Stenger.

record.title: Top of Sometsuke Katagami Sho Chiku Bai Namasu-Zara (pickle dish with cobalt stenciled three friends design)
Bottom of Sometsuke Katagami Sho Chiku Bai Namasu-Zara (pickle dish with cobalt stenciled three friends design)
Side of Sometsuke Katagami Sho Chiku Bai Namasu-Zara (pickle dish with cobalt stenciled three friends design)
Sometsuke Katagami Sho Chiku Bai Namasu-Zara (pickle dish with cobalt stenciled three friends design)
record.source: Asian American Comparative Collection
record.description: This katagami stenciled namasu-zara features depictions of sho chiku bai in a central medallion and a linear katagami design on the exterior. The pickle dish has a scalloped rim and a janome (bull's-eye or snake-eye) recess on the base (Ross 2012:10).
record.dimensions: Rim= 14 cm, footring= 8.5 cm, height= 3.8 cm
record.man-range: Most popular during the Meiji (1868-1912) era

record.source: Asian American Comparative Collection
record.description: This Saka-bin, or Western-style sake bottle, is the smaller of the two in the AACC collection. It is made of hanjiki, a type of 'half-porcelain,' and has a greyish-white exterior glaze.

record.title: Interior of Suribachi (grinding bowl) [1]
record.dimensions: Suribachi (grinding bowl)

record.title: Exterior of Suribachi (grinding bowl) [1]
record.dimensions: Suribachi (grinding bowl)

record.title: Suribachi (grinding bowl) [1]
record.source: Burke Museum of Natural History and Culture, US Air Force Collection
record.description: Suribachi bowl body fragment with parallel incised lines on the interior that were likely created by combing (kushime) the paste. Suribachi's texturized interior are used to grind ingredients like sesame seeds. They often are made of a buff paste that is covered by an opaque reddish-brown to brown glaze (Ross 2012:13; Crueger et al. 2006:295).
record.dimensions: n/a
record.man-range: Meiji (1868-1912) through early Showa (1926-1989) eras
